column4: Title
Observations on the colony activity of the asian hornet vespa velutina lepeletier 1836 (hymenoptera: Vespidae: Vespinae) in france
column5: Annales de la Societe entomologique de France (N.S.)
column37: Captive colony: 25-50 honeybees/day (mean 37.5). Free-living nests: 84.8% of flesh pellets (145/171) were Apis mellifera thoraxes
column39: attacks throughout day with peak in morning
column40: average 4 trials needed to catch honeybee

column4: Predation pressure dynamics study of the recently introduced honeybee killer Vespa velutina : learning from the enemy
column37: Predation lasted 5 months. ART site: 916 hornets trapped
column38: VIL site: 1894 hornets trapped. Predation affected by wind speed, temperature, humidity. Peak captures: 106 (ART) and 217 (VIL) on 12 Nov

column4: Native prey and invasive predator patterns of foraging activity: The case of the yellow-legged hornet predation at european honeybee hives.
column36: Video monitoring of 2 hives. Predation pressure increased during season. Number of honeybee captures showed maximum peak for intermediate number of V. velutina. Captures increased during midday hours

column4: Spatial distribution of Vespa velutina individuals hunting at domestic honeybee hives: heterogeneity at a local scale
column36: Capture-mark-recapture study. 360 hornets captured and tagged. More than 50% marked hornets recaptured. Estimated 350 hornets visiting patch daily. 88% recaptured in front of different hives but distribution was aggregative

column4: Defensive behaviour of Apis mellifera against Vespa velutina in France: Testing whether European honeybees can develop an effective collective defence against a new predator
column35: Investigated 8 apiaries and 95 colonies. A. mellifera in France exhibit inefficient and unorganized defence against V. velutina. Colonies subjected to either low or high levels of predation

column4: Daily and seasonal extranidal behaviour variations in the invasive yellow-legged hornet, vespa velutina lepeletier (hymenoptera: Vespidae)
column36: Video monitoring of two colonies during growth from August to November. Three major behaviours monitored: nest maintenance, patrolling on nest, foraging flights

column4: How apis mellifera behaves with its invasive hornet predator vespa velutina
column35: Video monitoring of two hives. Balling behaviour reported for first time under natural conditions in A. mellifera against V. velutina. Number of hornets impacted honeybee foraging and defence behaviours

column4: The invasion, provenance and diversity of vespa velutina lepeletier (hymenoptera: Vespidae) in great britain
column36: First report in Great Britain. Single nest in Gloucestershire. Foraging activity largely restricted within 700m of nest

column4: A pan-European epidemiological study reveals honey bee colony survival depends on beekeeper education and disease control
column35: Pan-European study. Overwinter losses ranged 2-32%. High summer losses likely to follow high winter losses. Hobbyist beekeepers had double winter mortality compared to professionals

column4: Activity rhythm and action range of workers of the invasive hornet predator of honeybees Vespa velutina, measured by radio frequency identification tags.
column37: RFID study. Homing ability up to 5000m. Foraging range estimated ca. 1000m around nest. Most flight activity 07:00-20:00. 318 individuals released at different distances, 71 individuals monitored 24/24 for 2 months

column4: A cost-benefit approach for prioritizing invasive species
column36: Theoretical framework for prioritization. Mentions V. velutina: from 2 nests in 2004 to 1613 nests in 2007, covering 150000 km2 in 2008. No coordinated control policy implemented as of 2009

column4: Predation of the invasive Asian hornet affects foraging activity and survival probability of honey bees in Western Europe
column36: Field observations and model simulations. Evidence of bee foragers' homing failures and foraging paralysis. Hornet-induced disturbances affect colony dynamics and winter survival. Foraging paralysis is important mechanism underlying winter colony collapse

column4: The impact of the invasive species Vespa velutina on honeybees: A new approach based on oxidative stress.
column5: The Science of the total environment

column4: A biodiversity-friendly method to mitigate the invasive Asian hornet's impact on European honey bees
column36: Tested beehive muzzle on 22 pairs of colonies. Muzzle did not reduce homing failure but drastically reduced foraging paralysis. Increased survival probability up to 51% in high hornet abundance context

column4: Monitoring of honey bee colony losses: a special issue
The economic cost of control of the invasive yellow-legged Asian hornet
column5: NeoBiota : advancing research on alien species and biological invasions
column36: Nest destruction cost €23 million 2006-2015 in France. Yearly cost increasing. Could reach €11.9M (France), €9.0M (Italy), €8.6M (UK) if species fills climatically suitable distribution

column4: Biological invasions in France: Alarming costs and even more alarming knowledge gaps
column5: NeoBiota : advancing research on alien species and biological invasions
column38: Total costs (1993-2018): US$ 11,535 million. Average annual costs: US$ 444 million. Observed costs only: US$ 1,280 million

column4: A metabarcoding tool to detect predation of the honeybee Apis mellifera and other wild insects by the invasive Vespa velutina
column37: Honeybee DNA detected in 100% of faecal pellets, 70% of jaws, 40% of stomachs. Honeybee reads: 75% of total reads (79,143/108,979)

column4: Economic costs of invasive alien species in Spain
column5: NeoBiota : advancing research on alien species and biological invasions
column37: Total robust costs: US$ 261 million (€ 232 million) from 1997 to 2022. Cost increase: US$ 4 million/year before 2000 → US$ 15 million/year in recent years

column4: Not just honeybees: predatory habits of Vespa velutina (Hymenoptera: Vespidae) in France
column5: Annales de la Societe entomologique de France (N.S.)
column36: Studied 16 nests. Identified 2151 prey pellets. Generalist predator: honeybees 38.1%, flies 29.9%, social wasps 19.7%, 159+ species. Urban colonies prey more on honeybees, forest colonies more on wasps. Peak predation early October. Single nest consumes average 11.32 kg insect biomass/season

column4: Monitoring study in honeybee colonies stressed by the invasive hornet vespa velutina.
column37: Hornet sightings monitored via photos. First sighting 2020: 12 June
column38: First sighting 2021: 26 May. Daily activity period 7:00-21:00 h. Peak months: September 2020, October 2021
column40: Photos every hour from 6:00 h to 0:00 h

column4: Effectiveness of electric harps in reducing Vespa velutina predation pressure and consequences for honey bee colony development.
column38: Protected hives showed 88.8% less predation pressure. Foraging paralysis threshold: HRH > 0.8 hornets/hive/10 min. Protected colonies: 77.8% survival
column40: Foraging activity significantly affected by HRH and month
column41: Workers from unprotected hives were 6.7% lighter than protected hives

column4: Chemical and genetic evidences that multiple hornet colonies attack honeybee colonies
column37: Study focuses on hornet colony identification attacking apiaries. Chemical variation: at least 2 chemically homogeneous groups per apiary

column4: The invasive hornet Vespa velutina : distribution, impacts and management options
Density of predating Asian hornet's at hives disturbs the 3D flight performance of honey bees and decreases predation success.
column36: Predation success 2.4% of recorded interactions (126/5,175). Success 4x higher for bees entering hive (69.46%) vs leaving (15.27%). Peak success at ~8 hornets
column37: Flight speed and curvature affected by hornet density. Bees entering: speed and curvature increase with hornet density. Bees leaving: speed decreases
column38: Flight performance changes with hornet density. Hovering behavior differs between bees entering/leaving and hornets
column39: Peak hornet activity at 1 pm, peak honey bee activity at 3 pm

column4: Quantifying the impact of an invasive hornet on bombus terrestris colonies.
column37: Study on Bombus terrestris, not Apis mellifera. Predation attempts observed: 125 total, 0% success rate. Colony weight negatively correlated with hornet counts

column4: Molecular identification of asian hornet vespa velutina nigrithorax prey from larval gut contents: a promising method to study the diet of an invasive pest.
column5: Animals : an open access journal from MDPI
column38: Honey bee detection: Present in 25 of 38 larvae (65.8%). Honey bee detection by nest: 4 of 5 nests. Jersey nest: 20.5% of reads

column4: Testing the selectiveness of electric harps: a mitigation method for reducing Asian hornet impact at beehives
column38: V. velutina: 90.5% of all insects trapped. Native insects (excluding honeybees): Mean 1.2% of all insects trapped. Risk of damage to local entomofauna: Very low

column4: How stressors disrupt honey bee biological traits and overwintering mechanisms.
Management of honey bee (Hymenoptera: Apidae) colonies under yellow-legged hornet (Hymenoptera: Vespidae) pressure
column37: Review article, no primary data. References reported losses: 30-80% (European beekeepers). Indirect costs: 10% increase in beekeeping costs

column4: Broad ecological threats of an invasive hornet revealed through a deep sequencing approach.
column5: The Science of the total environment
column38: Apis mellifera: Found in every nest, average prevalence 98.1%. Total OTUs detected: 1,449. Species-level identification: 55.1% of OTUs. Most frequently predated: A. mellifera (98.1%), Vespula vulgaris (52.2%), Calliphora vicina (51.7%)

column4: Assessing predation pressure of Vespa velutina on local fauna through DNA metabarcoding
column38: Apis mellifera identified in prey composition (22.55% of Apidae family). Total OTUs identified: 102. Shared OTUs across all nests: 2 (A. mellifera and Calliphora vicina)

column4: Long-term Vespa velutina nigrithorax pressure: Honey bee risk survival to alien invasion
column37: Total hornets counted: 11,406. Risk threshold: ≥5 hornets poses risk to colony survival. Peak months: July-October vary by apiary and year
column38: Foraging paralysis observed when hornet pressure is high
column40: Photos every hour from 6:00 am to 11:00 pm
